title: A multi-agent system is built from autonomous, asynchronous agents that have their own local goals and can interact with other agents in the shared environment.
Each agent, in this case,
Animal
c
has a genotype that determines its behavior - the probability of moving in either direction.
On each tick of the simulation, each animal makes a move. Moving costs energy. Energy can be acquired by eating plants, that grow in random places on the map. The
dark green area (jungle)
h
teal_background
in the center of the map has a higher probability of growing plants.
When two animals meet on the same field, they can breed, if they both have enough stored energy. The offspring is born with a genotype that is a combination of its parent's genes.
Animals with no energy are considered dead and are removed from the simulation.

The simulation is implemented in Java and JavaFX. It's multithreaded and allows running multiple copies with the same starting conditions. Each instance can be paused or can generate a summarized report to a file.
Starting parameters can be set in
parameters.json
c
Animal color changes from
yellow
h
yellow_background
to
red
h
orange_background
based on their level of stored energy.
The largest group of animals that share the same genotype is displayed in
blue.
h
blue_background
You can select any animal to track it and view detailed information about it in the dashboard.

description: This is a weekly newsletter about tech, media, and culture. To receive this newsletter in your inbox each week, subscribe here: First, a big personal update: this week, I joined the team at Index Ventures. I feel incredibly lucky to work with this team. At Index, we invest across stages-from seed to early-stage to growth.

title: The New Generation of Labor Marketplaces and the Future of Work
description: by Pete Flint (@PeteFlint). Pete is a General Partner at NFX, a seed-stage venture firm based in San Francisco. With unemployment expected to reach 20-30%, on par with the Great Depression, the COVID-19 crisis heralds a once-in-a-century moment in the job market.

title: The passion economy and the future of professional services
description: Let's start by clarifying that the much-hyped 'creator' economy is a subset of the passion economy and not the same thing. In 2019, Li Jin, now widely considered to be the godmother of the passion economy, wrote an essay titled " The Passion Economy and the Future of Work."

title: The Crypto Future of Work

Building The Best Tools for Creators, with Joseph Albanese
description: For our guest this week on Means of Creation we welcomed Joseph Albanese, co-founder and CEO of Stir! As we've discussed on the show before, creators are becoming a larger and larger part of the economy. But these individuals don't just have to create content, but have to be the CEO, CFO and COO of their business.

title: Why the Future of Startups are Studios
description: Startups are risky, risky business. As you set out to build the next big company, the path is littered with the logos of fallen comrades. You are trying to thread a needle in a wind tunnel. Founders take on this crazy risk because the possible reward is huge.

Iâ€™d like to share a visual metaphor that Iâ€™ve found quite useful over the past few years when trying to understand and reason about different people and ideas.
Imagine the existence of an objective, omnipotent entity ala God that associates every human being with a virtual 3D bubble.

Visualize one of these bubbles surrounding every person that you meet, with the size of each bubble being proportional to that personâ€™s aggregate life experience, world understanding, and self-awareness.
The more knowledge, life experience, and world understanding you gain, the larger your wisdom bubble grows.
The more sheltered, inexperienced, and ignorant you are, the smaller your wisdom bubble shrinks.

For the more mathematically inclined, you could imagine these bubbles as high dimensional surfaces where each dimension corresponds to some concrete aspect of knowledge. This abstraction is a lot harder to visualize and reason about, however, so for the purposes of this thought experiment letâ€™s stick with the projection of these high dimensional surfaces onto three-dimensional spheres.
Now let's explore the implications of this thought experiment a bit.
Natural properties that should hold true for all wisdom bubbles would include:

All babies would start with small, roughly equal-sized, non-zero volume bubbles. They would have a positive volume at birth due to built-in knowledge and behaviors that all humans start with. (eg no clean slate)

The size of your bubble wouldnâ€™t necessarily grow monotonically over the course of your life. In other words, itâ€™s possible for the size of your bubble to grow and shrink in response to stimuli as you grow older. Some examples of experiences that may cause your bubble to shrink would be the onset of a major depression or joining a misguided cult from which your world view is either temporarily or irrevocably damaged.
The size of your parentâ€™s bubbles would be a strong factor affecting the rate at which your bubble would grow during adolescence, with this factor weakening as you grow older.

description: "We predict that serverless computing will grow to dominate the future of cloud computing." -Berkeley CS Dept, Cloud computing simplified: a Berkeley view on serverless computing Bringing stateful services, fast data/streaming, and the power of reactive technologies to the Cloud Native ecosystem breaks down the final impediment standing in the way of a Serverless platform for general-purpose application development -with true elastic scalability, high resilience, and global deployment, in the Kubernetes ecosystem.

title: The State of the Serverless Art
description: Over the past 2 years, the Hydro team I lead at Berkeley's RISELab has been running hard and fast in the area of serverless computing. We designed and built a stateful Functions-as-a-Service platform called Cloudburst. I like to say "Cloudburst puts the state into the state-of-the-art" in serverless computing.

title: Temporal.io: Build Invincible Apps
description: Microservices Orchestration It guarantees that workflow code eventually completes, has built-in support for exponential activity retries, and simplifies the coding of the compensation logic with native Saga pattern support. You can define retries, rollbacks, or even a human intervention step in the case of failure.

title: NFTs make the internet ownable
description: Before tech, I was an artist manager in music. When I started the firm, I believed one thing about the music industry very firmly: ownership endows power. Typically, labels had ownership over the music, and thus, power over artists.

title: You have an awesome startup idea.
You're not a programmer, but that's okay.
Maybe you have some relevant domain expertise, maybe you have some prior startup experience, maybe you've done extensive market research, maybe you even have some product mockups.
Now all you need is a developer (or developers??) to build your product.
But you need money to hire developers.
Investors are hesitant to give you money.. you're told to come back once you have a technical co-founder...
But how do you find one of these elusive creatures? And how do you convince them to join you? And is this even the best path to take??
If this sounds at all familiar, then this article is for you.

For context, I'm a relatively experienced technical co-founder with multiple exits under my belt. And even though I love software development, I'm here to tell you that for most early stage startups, you no longer need a technical co-founder.
I talk to aspiring founders all the time, and I can't tell you how often I come across some variation of the above.
Specific questions founders have aren't always so direct, but the underlying thought process is often very similar. I get questions like:
How do I find a technical co-founder? (really direct)
Where can I find cheap developers to build my MVP?
